PropertyList.title: de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter
PropertyList.line: Nose wheel steering is controlled by the lever behind the pilot's yoke.
If it's disabled in the menu dialog (DHC-6 -> Nose wheel steering), the nose wheel is controlled via rudder
To open/close the doors, just click on it.
When not starting up the engines on asphalt, you have to switch on the intake deflectors. Otherwise the engines will fail.
If the outside temperature is below 0 dec C, you have to switch on the pitot heat and the prop deice!
The maximum speed is 170 knots, up to 6700 ft. Above that it decreases by 3 knots each 1000 ft.
Technical data (DHC-6-300):
Length: 15.77 m/51 ft 9 in
Wingspan: 19.81 m/65 ft 0 in
Height: 5.91 m/19 ft 4 in
Service ceiling: 7620 m/25000 ft
Range with max fuel, no payload: aprox. 1430 km/775 nm
Maximum landing weight: 5,579 kg/12300 lb
Powerplant: 2x Pratt and Whitney Canada PT6A-27
Power: 2x 463 kW
Stall speed in landing config (Vs0): 58 KIAS
Stall speed in cruise config (Vs1): 80 KIAS
Maximum Operating Speed (Vmo) up to 6,700 ft: 170 KIAS
Maximum Operating Speed (Vmo) up to 10,000 ft MSL: 160 KIAS
Maximum Operating Speed (Vmo) up to 15,000 ft MSL: 145 KIAS
Maximum Operating Speed (Vmo) up to 20,000 ft MSL: 130 KIAS
Maximum Operating Speed (Vmo) up to 25,000 ft MSL: 115 KIAS
Typical Cruise Speed (up to 10000 ft MSL): around 150 KIAS
PropertyList.text:
Some information about the Twin Otter: The DHC-6 Twin Otter is a Canadian 19-passenger STOL aircraft developed by de Havilland Canada. It's first flight was on May 20th, 1965 and it was produced until 1988. Since 2008 Viking Air produces the Twin Otter in License as DHC-6-400 Series. Till today there were built more than 900 Twin Otters. It's STOL abilities and high rate of climb have made it ideal for regional cargo/passenger transport and for MEDEVAC flights. In USA and in Europe it is a popular aircraft in the commercial skydiving sector. The aircraft's powerful engines make the DHC-6 a suitable bush plane for inaccessible and remote terrain in many development countries. The version of the Twin Otter in FlightGear is the DHC-6-300 Series
